# What is the relationship between density and specific volume?


# How do you use specific volume?


## Mass Density and Specific Volume


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\textbf{Mass Density (Density)}$ $\rightarrow$ measure of mass per volume
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
SI units: $\mathrm{kg/m^3}$
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\rho$ $= \frac{m}{V}$ $= \frac{1}{}$
:::


::: {.fragment}
![](Special_V.png){.absolute top="256" left="140" width="60" height="60"}
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
$\textbf{Specific Volume}$ $\rightarrow$ Reciprocal of mass density
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
SI units: $\mathrm{m^3/kg}$
:::


::: {.fragment}
![](Special_V.png){.absolute top="465" left="-30" width="80" height="80"}
:::




::: {.fragment .lower}
$\text{ }\text{ }$ $= \frac{V}{m}$ $= \frac{1}{\rho}$
:::


## Molar Density and Molar Volume


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\textbf{Molar Density}$ $\rightarrow$ measure of # of moles per volume
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
SI units: $\text{g-mol}\mathrm{/m^3}$ (same units as concentration)
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\rho$ $= \frac{n}{V}$ $= \frac{1}{}$
:::


::: {.fragment}
![](Special_V.png){.absolute top="256" left="140" width="60" height="60"}
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
$\textbf{Molar Volume}$ $\rightarrow$ reciprocal of molar density
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
SI units: $\mathrm{m^3/}\text{g-mol}$
:::


::: {.fragment}
![](Special_V.png){.absolute top="465" left="-30" width="80" height="80"}
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
$\text{ }\text{ }$ $= \frac{V}{n}$ $= \frac{1}{\rho}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}


We reuse the symbols for mass density and specific volume for molar density and molar volume. </br> Check the units to determine which is being used!


:::


## Specific Gravity


::: {.fragment}
Specific Gravity $\rightarrow$ ratio of density to a reference density
:::


::: {.fragment .centered}
Specific gravity = $\frac{\rho}{\mathrm{\rho_{ref}}}$
:::


:::{.fragment .bitlower}
Most common reference density $\rightarrow$ liquid water at $4^{\circ}\text{C}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
$\rho \text{ } \mathrm{_{ H_2O(\textit{l})}} \text{ }4^{\circ}\text{C}$ = 1000 $\mathrm{kg/m^3}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower .bitright}
= 1.000 $\mathrm{g/cm^3}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower .bitright}
= 62.43 $\mathrm{lb_m/ft^3}$
:::


# What is the relationship between molar density and molar concentration?


# How would you use molar density?


## Concentration


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\textbf{Molar Concentration}$ (Concentration) $\rightarrow$ # of moles per unit volume
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower .centered}
$\mathrm{C_A =} \frac{\mathrm{n_A}}{V}$
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
For an ideal gas, can be calculated as:
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower .centered}
$\mathrm{C_A =} \frac{\mathrm{n_A}}{V} = \frac{\mathrm{P_A}}{RT}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
$\textbf{Mass Concentration}$ $\rightarrow$ mass per unit volume (same units as density)
:::


::: {.fragment .lower}
Most often used for quantities of salinity
:::


::: {.fragment .lower .centered}
$\mathrm{C_A =} \frac{\mathrm{m_A}}{V}$
:::


## Mass, Molar, and Volumetric Flow Rates


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\textbf{Mass Flow Rate}$ $\rightarrow$ $\frac{\text{amount of mass flowing past a given location}}{\text{period of time}}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower .centered}
$\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{m}_{i_{in}}}$ = $\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{m}_{i_{out}}}$ $\text{               (open, steady state)}$
:::


::: {.fragment .evenlower}
$\textbf{Molar Flow Rate}$ $\rightarrow$ $\frac{\text{# of moles flowing past a given location}}{\text{period of time}}$
:::




::: {.fragment .lotslower .centered}
$\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{n}_{i_{in}}}$ = $\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{n}_{i_{out}}}$ ($\text{open, steady state,}$ $\textbf{no reactions}$)
:::


## Mass, Molar, and Volumetric Flow Rates (cont.)


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
$\textbf{Volumetric Flow Rate}$ $\rightarrow$ $\frac{\text{volume of fluid flowing past a given location}}{\text{period of time}}$
:::


::: {.fragment .lower .centered}
$\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{V}_{i_{in}}}$ $\neq$ $\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{V}_{i_{out}}}$ ($\text{in general}$)
:::

::: {.longq}
# You have a stopwatch, a measuring cup, a pair of calipers, and fluid flowing in a tube at a constant rate. </br> How would you measure the fluid velocity?
:::


## Mass, Molar, and Volumetric Flow Rates (cont.)


$\textbf{Volumetric Flow Rate}$ $\rightarrow$ $\frac{\text{volume of fluid flowing past a given location}}{\text{period of time}}$




::: {.bitlower .centered}
$\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{V}_{i_{in}}}$ $\neq$ $\sum \mathrm{\overset{.}{V}_{i_{out}}}$ ($\text{in general}$)
:::




::: {.fragment .lower}
Given a specific location in space and instant in time, the following relationship exists betweenn the the volumetric flow rate ($\mathrm{\overset{.}{V}}$), the average fluid velocity ($\textit{u}$), and the cross-sectional area of the flow ($\textit{A}$):
:::


::: {.fragment .lower .centered}
$\mathrm{\overset{.}{V}}$ = $\textit{uA}$
:::




::: {.fragment .lower}
For an open, steady state system, the previous expression is true at any location in the system.
:::


## Mass, Molar, and Volumetric Flow Rates (cont.)


::: { .bitlower .fragment}
Relationship between mass flow rate ($\mathrm{\overset{.}{m}}$) and volumetric flow rate ($\mathrm{\overset{.}{V}}$):
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower .centered}
$\mathrm{\overset{.}{m}}$ = $\mathrm{\overset{.}{V}}$ $\rho$
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower .centered}
$\mathrm{\overset{.}{V}_{in}}$ $\mathrm{\rho_{in}}$ =  $\mathrm{\overset{.}{V}_{out}}$ $\mathrm{\rho_{out}}$ (open, steady-state system, 1 inlet & 1 outlet)
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
Don't Forget!
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
Volume $\neq$ conserved quantity
:::


::: {.fragment .bitlower}
mass/molar flowrate $\rightarrow$ constant $\neq$ volumetric flowrate $\rightarrow$ constant
:::
